commentBody:
Easy month continues...23.3% faster than my Wed average for me this time.  The more things change...

But one thing that did change was that the "new format" for comments actually went live sometime today.  When it was first offered as an option, I tried it for a day or two, and went back to the old one, hoping they'd eventually give up on the new format.  It just doesn't work well here, where people reply to an original post, then someone replies to the reply, and then several other people reply to subsequent replies.

This makes for a hierarchy of progressively more indented replies.  And then, you have to notice that there are replies to replies that actively have to be opened.

Reading elsewhere in the paper, I see that this phenomenon is unique to the crossword comments (and maybe some of the other games comments).  Most news articles' comment sections do not have long threads of replies and replies to replies.  

In other words, it might work really well for the rest of the paper, but it's horrid here.

I guess we just get used to checking for threads that are totally hidden.  But I've found myself paying more attention to opening hidden replies than actually paying attention to what people are saying.

Sad.  Easy puzzle, difficult comment section.

18A gave it away for me.

Thanks, Jerry Lee (and Joseph).
Nice one.  Cute using OCTAD and not OCTet.

Love the theme with GOODNESS GRACIOUS GREAT BALLS OF FIRE.

There was a few clues I got entirely with crossing clues like EEO as an acronym I've never heard of and OPI the makeup brand.

The square that gave me the most trouble was CATERS/CAPS OFF.  First I had TOPS OFF and never heard of CAPS OFF as an alternative to that.  And because I kept seeing the "Does dishes" clue in terms of washing them instead of serving them I was wondering if it was something like WATERS and maybe the down clue was some new slang term I didn't know.

I‚Äôm tempted to talk of shoes and ships and sealing wax and cabbages and kings, but I guess I should share my view of the Wednesday puzzle.  GOODNESSGRACIOUS, that was a quick one.  It was a nice touch to slip GOODNESSGRACIOUS into the puzzle without mentioning it in the revealer.
There's no circled letters for me which makes things a little confusing but this was a fun one.
Love the EDGES on the edge.
First day this week I haven't beaten my average time, but I solved with no hints in just a few seconds over my average so I'll take it! Octet/ad got me stuck for a while, along with the dishes one.
Absolutely loved that clip of Jerry Lee Lewis at the piano on the Ed Sullivan Show.  What a showman!  Great Balls of Fire indeed!!!

GOODNESS GRACIOUS, this was a fun one. GREAT BALLS OF FIRE will forever remind me of Goose singing in Top Gun‚Ä¶ https://youtu.be/2R-5hI93tV0?si=u9lniYFk3dUZ3u0n And the reprise in Maverick‚Ä¶ https://youtu.be/pVcMsjyKlaM?si=XarND-pGNP8n4k2X EJECTS of course reminded me of Goose once again üò¢ I always appreciate when a puzzle takes me back in time and this one was a winner in that respect. Thank you, Joseph.

How do constructors come up with such clever ideas, that‚Äôs the burning question. 

Masterful construction. Four balls of FIRE, each with the first letter starting in a different position. BEST OF ALL (and somewhat surprisingly), GOOD GRACIOUS and GREAT BALLS OF FIRE are both debuts. 

I got the theme quickly, and even though it didn‚Äôt shake my nerves and rattle my brain, it was fun! 

Well done, Joseph.
So there‚Äôs another brand of nail-polish, three letters beginning with I.
Why is there always an issue trying to open the answer key
Finished in just over half my usual Wednesday time.  Barely noticed the theme, and it didn't enhance my puzzle experience, so this really felt like a Monday or Tuesday to me.
I have no idea what the word play is with CATERS. I see it‚Äôs mentioned in today‚Äôs column but no explanation is given. I guess it should be obvious then. But I‚Äôm not getting it.

Unsure what the issue is with this puzzle‚Äîthere are no circled letters. I‚Äôve had them before, but don‚Äôt in this puzzle. Brightness all the way, tried all color schemes (light, blue, dark). No circled letters.

It would be useful in night mode if the layer for circles were in white.  I only play in dark mode, and typically have my brightness set to as minimum as needed to read.  Since the letters entered are typically white (blue if auto check is enabled), the black circle layer on a dark grey and black grid is lost. 

I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs someone with younger eyes that will say they see it.  And good for them. But my eyes are now old, and I would like to be able to accomplish the puzzle with the additional clues available in dark mode. 

Thank you for coming to my talk.

Oh good gawwwd, the new comment system has gone live [shudders]. Has the world forgotten New Coke?

A really fun puzzle. Since I‚Äôve already dug up the 80‚Äôs, anyone remember Dennis Quaid as Jerry Lee Lewis? No one‚Äôs ever belted out, ‚ÄúGoodness gracious, great balls of fire!‚Äù quite the same way. (Yes, I had a tween crush on him. What of it?)

One more personal memory the puzzle stirred up. I used to sometimes speak for The Dog since she was limited to having very expressive eyes (one with a black patch and eyelashes, the other with white), a very wriggly body, and one incredibly active stumpy tail. ‚ÄúOh goodness gracious‚Äù had somehow become her signature reply. Now that she‚Äôs gone, whenever I say, ‚ÄúOh goodness gracious,‚Äù to some smartaleck comment from my friends, one of them always replies with, ‚ÄúAs Tessie always used to say,‚Äù and another will supply, ‚ÄúAnd she said it quite often.‚Äù

I‚Äôll never stop missing that dog like crazy. Thanks, Joseph, for making me smile. 

Have a good night, all.

Thank you Top Gun

Also I don't think it's a thing for other states, but it's absolutely mandatory that you know the state bird if you live in Minnesota
Solved in 40% less time than average.  Are the puzzles getting easier?  Wish there was an easy way to see for a period of time how my solve time has compared to my average.

A nice reminder of growing up with that music, and a quick finish.

Thanks, Joseph!
I was getting back to civilian life in 1957. Did I really not notice that song, or is it just another of the myriad things I've entirely forgotten?
Still scratching my head how REFS are play callers, even with the question mark.

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody: Delightful.
This puzzle had some quite interesting and fun choices for the shorter (3 or 4-letter) clues.  Three different spelled-out letter clues made me wonder if that was going to be part of the theme.

Jerry Lee Lewis was great for a bedtime lullaby!  Loved it.

The puzzle was fun too.

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
If we all always reply to the original poster,  we will defeat this new comment "system", won't we? All it would take would be manually typing @[person we're replying to]

Like how we did it last year or the year before that when replies to replies were not visible, at all.

Of course it would be best if the IT team stopped making things worse, but I've lost all hope of that.
Yet another fun puzzle, after so so so many other fun puzzles. I love crosswords! I always look forward to it.

The word WALRUS seems so compact and self-confident, like the great pinniped it describes, that i had not considered its etymology. But of course, a headslap moment: Wikipedia tells me it probably comes from the Old Norse hvalr +  hross, or ‚Äúwhale horse‚Äù! Of course! 

(We will all recognize the hvalr root from ‚Äúnarwhal‚Äù, which gets nar ‚Äúcorpse‚Äù from the color of its cadaverously mottled skin - who knew?)

Actually Wikipedia mentions a second Walrus theory, just to muddy the pristine arctic waters i am enjoying: it may come from the Dutch words wal 'shore' and reus 'giant'. I much prefer the Old Norse version!

Not too shabby. I got a bit stuck on CAPS OFF, and FORMAL as a noun - not used by me, and FROSTS is fairly unfamiliar. Fortunately I got AMOS from the crossers, and LORDE. 

On my phone I couldn't see the circles, but they are obvious on the laptop I used later. Nicely constructed.

I liked the puzzle, a nice Wednesday. But 62A [cr√®me de la cr√®me] solving to BESTOFALL doesn't seem quite right. 

If you were describing a plan that went especially well you might list some of the reasons why and then add, for example, and maybe with a grin, "and BEST OF ALL I solved the puzzle in record time." We're talking about a little something extra that arises from the context.

I guess BEST OF ALL could literally mean cr√©me de la cr√©me but it just seems a little odd used that way. I'm okay with best of the rest, that seems more natural, and it rhymes, but that's not the gold medal, it's coming in fourth.

But that's just me. Goo goo ga joob.
A few seconds off my average, with a number of tricky ones, but nothing to complain about. (Not that I come here to complain.)

Took a five hour break before finishing and ended up about a minute slower. Enjoyed the theme which I feel was smokin' hot. I feel like these last few days have been a training run for what might be a challenging Thursday. Maybe a stonking Big Air Winter Olympics theme perhaps! üèÇüèÖ

Who here did not think "GREAT BALLS OF FIRE" as soon as they filled in GOODNESS GRACIOUS? They go together like a WALRUS and a mustache. One of my favorites: https://youtu.be/Ricp8I7nquE?si=eURQAjZ5cdcxhCKP

Well, I picked up on the musical theme right away, except that:
1) it's ten letters, not sixteen
2) it's classic country-western, not classic rock.

So, it‚Äôs been plain to see that the Times team has been tinkering with the difficulty level of the days of the week.  My thoughts on this are as an experienced solver whose favorite days are Friday and Saturday, as they require brain skills that accrue with time, skills that are satisfying and pleasurable to employ.

I would be selfish to ask that all days be at this level ‚Äì the week should cover all solvers.  But please, team, keep these two days high-difficulty-level.  Don‚Äôt tinker with that.  Let new solvers develop their skills through the week, to where one day they can earn their tough and tricky puzzles ‚Äì start very easy on Monday and end very hard on Saturday.  Let solvers at every level have their day(s).

That is, don‚Äôt blanket-easify the week, making every day easier.  Keep those weekend days tough as ever.  Thank you.

"The roof I own, it owns me back/ Mortgage shadows turn skies black.": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EbOK0ZJs1wE&list=RDEbOK0ZJs1wE&start_radio=1 !!! (FWIW, I could not find anything out about Cleo Cervantes or VALIAN MUSIC which did lead directly back to this song/vid.)

This is Joseph‚Äôs second music-related theme in a row, his last being a Sondheim tribute. It‚Äôs also another where he features grid art, with those four-square circles ‚Äì I don‚Äôt ever remember seeing those before (and please, anyone, correct me if you have). Let me remind you that Joseph designed the puzzle with the cutest grid art I‚Äôve ever seen ‚Äì https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/16/2022 (spoiler alert: this puzzle image has the answers filled in). Those larger circles today compared to the one-square circles we normally see in puzzles, are indeed ‚Äúgreat balls‚Äù. Lovely touch to have those fireballs symmetrical, and to not refer to GOODNESS GRACIOUS in the clue to the revealer, that is, to let it come as a self-discovery. Just a terrific build overall. Joseph, you love Wednesdays, on which six of your seven Times puzzles have fallen. I love how well you emphasize the visual aspects of grids. Thank you for a fun and impressive outing!

My inner three-year-old expected flaming, spinning graphics along with the San Jose Strut. Even better, they could have had the full Jerry Lee Lewis song stand in for the usual music. (I'm easily amused, though. I and a friend of mine once walked in to a small country store in Alabama planning to buy a few fireworks, but ended up buying out their entire stock and making multiple trips back to the car with boxes and bags. The best one was one of the largest ones...it malfunctioned, and what was supposed to be a display lasting several minutes went up in a huge ball of flame and a deafening explosion that set off every car alarm for blocks.)

Had this been published on a Thursday, I also would have expected that none of the answers that crossed the "balls" would have made any sense until they "rotated" into place.
Loved the puzzle. Might be the easiest Sunday - Wednesday ever. But yeeesh. I guess I need an eye exam trying to see those circles in dark mode.
Like it was yesterday watching his fingers fly around the piano his hair flapping his body shaking toes tapping. I couldn‚Äôt wait to be a teenager.

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I‚Äôve inexplicably taken in the past nine years, it is my duty to inform you that this puzzle has an unusually high number of double letters, at 24, where unusual is 20 or more. This is the first time this year that this has happened, but alas, it comes with an asterisk, as this grid is a column wider than standard.  

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.

Not too long ago, we pondered SAPPHO's evocation of eros:

It is this that rouses a tumult
in my breast. At mere sight of you
my voice falters, my tongue
     is broken.

Straightway, a delicate fire runs in
my limbs; my eyes
are blinded and my ears
     thunder.

Sweat pours out: a trembling hunts
me down. I grow
paler than grass and lack little
     of dying.

Today, we get the immortal Jerry Lee Lewis's take on the same phenomenon:

You shake my nerves and you rattle my brain.
Too much love drives a man insane.
You broke my will, but what a thrill
GOODNESS GRACIOUS!  GREAT BALLS OF FIRE!!!

I can't decide which I prefer.
Why do we say Pair of Pants when we only mean one?
Am I the only one who entered SAFESEXT instead of SAFESEAT?

Only yesterday I learned a detail about Willem Dafoe in the movie Spider-Man. For the somewhat-famous mirror scene where his character Norman Osborn argues with his evil alter-ego Green Goblin (who incidentally throws small, pumpkin-shaped balls of fire), to add a flourish to his spiralling craziness, Dafoe took his CAPSOFF and showed his true and imperfect teeth.


I agree with (not Jerry Lee) Lewis below, regarding puzzle difficulty. ‚ÄúMediocre Balls of Warmth‚Äù would never have been famous.

I have to say, it is incredibly disheartening for those of us who are just becoming regular players to constantly read a litany of ‚ÄútHeSe PuZzLeS aRe ToO eAsY‚Äù in the comment section. To those of us embarking on this journey, the gradual shift in difficulty from Monday to Sunday is incredibly apparent. While I‚Äôm thrilled that you are all So Smart and these are Too Easy, maybe bask in the fact that you are improving at this skill set (as a consistent player should be)!  Remember that the puzzle makers are not here to constantly up the ante week to week, but rather day to day.

Nice Wednesday puzzle and a good workout for me. And really liked the theme. Oh...and a lot of lyrics in that song that might apply quite well to the process of working out a difficult puzzle. (I chew my nails and I twiddle my thumbs).

Was a bit surprised that the two grid-spanning theme answers were appearing for the first time, but then... realized that it's a 16 wide puzzle. That explains that. 

I'll put my puzzle find today in a reply.

....

So many mistakes again today, took me about 20 minutes to unpick them. After I filled the grid and got the finger wag I went to fix and I had 7 incorrect answers, only 2 of which made absolutely no sense on review.

I‚Äôll note this was the first time I‚Äôve smiled at an answer (in about 100 attempts at the crossword). I already had GREATBALLSOFFIRE when I got enough crosses to see the GOODNESSGRACIOUS answer and I did crack a smile, I think because of Top Gun.

I did notice near the end that the circles all had F I R E but as usual themes zoom over my head with the balls thing.

Found this harder than some of the other Wednesdays I‚Äôve completed, but I‚Äôm clearly in the minority on that.

Fun! Pretty breezy solve for me. But for some reason I initially wanted to enter RING OF FIRE into the theme answer. Instantly realizing there were too many spaces, I began trying THE RING OF FIRE and then BURNIN RING OF FIRE. Luckily I moved on after half a minute of that nonsense. Got to see The Killer Jerry Lee Lewis live at Wolf Trap VA around 1999, awesome show! The man could pound a piano.

Oh gawd the new comments section is awful. Why did they do this.

At least the puzzle was great! A lot of millennials will talk about "dad rock" and mean Led Zeppelin and the Eagles. But my dad was a bit older than most other millennials' dads, so to me "dad rock" means Elvis, Little Richard, and Jerry Lee Lewis. This puzzle was right up my alley!
Solving online and there aren‚Äôt any circled letters
Fun solve! I'm off to hop around the house on one foot (dancing to Great Balls of Fire), now that I've taken my shoe off at the door...
The Walrus and the Carpenter -- known to fans as an inspiration for "I am the Walrus" -- though Lennon later said maybe he identified with the wrong character on that one.

Goodness gracious! I simply adore the new look of the comments!!!

Like everyone else here I'm always complaining that this section isn't busy enough. Thanks for listening to us!

Some suggestions to make the forum even more interactive and fun:

1. CAPTCHA. Lots and lots of CAPTCHA.

2. The "Email me" box is the gift that keeps on giving! Each time more exciting than the last! But what if it said "Don't email me when my comment is not not not not not published" with the number of nots constantly changing?

3. Send us an 82-symbol code to enter manually before we can submit!

4. Nobody doesn't not like clicking to see replies. But wouldn't it be entertaining if each click revealed only one letter of a reply at a time?

Again, thank you! It's like you've given us all the big D of Delight!

Goodness gracious, I loved this theme! I was stuck on BABY, BABY LIGHT MY FIRE by the Doors because I never pay attention to years or times. LOL. Those circles were pretty large. LOL again. This puzzle just had me smiling all the way. That Jerry Lee was something ELSE! He was one wildcat! More puzzles like this, please :)

I haven‚Äôt noticed a change in the comment section for me yet, thank God!
Again a pretty by the books Wednesday.The crossword gods were kind with the song having two 15 letter phrases! Nothing too much OFINTEREST to highlight but nothing to complain about. Had CIS before CEE for  the Cookie Monster clue and was surprised at the non-gender related clueing, but of course since ‚Äúit‚Äôs‚Äù was in the clue CEE is correct.

I like the new comments format. Apparently change comes harder to some folks. If you think you have a better system, spell it out here ‚Äì you should be able to fit it into a 1500 word comment.
OTOH, I solve on an android phone, so maybe it really is a mess on other platforms.
Goodness gracious! I was falling into a Burning Ring of Fire until I got to 57A, and had to exchane my rings for balls.

Didn't we just see Mr. Gangi recently?  (Welcome both times, of course.
TOP OFF before CAPS was the only minor misstep.
Couldn't the puzzle have included Wm SaFIRE or some dalmations--for local color or authenticity, you know?
When I "smile broadly,"  it's a GRIN; when I keep smiling and pink up, I BEAM.  Or so I would say.

In 1957 (I was 10) I attended a birthday party that was a trip to The Temple Theater in Ft. Smith, AR, and the film was "Jailhouse Rock," starring (who else?) Elvis.  The slightly older girls in the back of the theater screamed so much that we couldn't hear the dialogue.  I was SO annoyed... (just a bit too young to swoon.)  We didn't have a TV, and we didn't listen to much radio, though I recall "Hound-dog"...I had outgrown Pinky Lee a while back, but had no attraction that was a replacement.  Simpler times.
Had to try commenting to see what all the fuss was about. Not seeing it yet?
I‚Äôm perplexed by all the discussion about the new comment system.  It looks just the same to me.
Good morning! Gettin' my Top Gun on....Goodness gracious! Have a good Wednesday!

If, as it appears, that is a comet displayed betwixt the sculptures, then of course it is not a great ball of fire, but rather the more seasonally-appropriate dirty ball of snow (and ice, and rocks, and other astronomical detritus).
The puzzle in which Pants are pairs & Shoe is one. I like twists of logic almost as much as Cookie Monster likes his chocolate chip Cee‚Äôs.
Cute puzzle. Lots of old-school fillers, apropos to the theme.
The circles didn‚Äôt render on iOS for me. Still a good puzzle.

Aaaand now I‚Äôll have that song in my head all day!

Fun solve, I really enjoyed that.

Solid theme, nicely handled, with GOODNESSGRACIOUS, GREATBALLSOFFIRE---these gave us 16 columns today---and four "balls of FIRE" (each of which offered FIRE in a clockwise pattern, with all four possible starting positions for the F represented).

Nice Wednesday puzzle. Certainly nothing to SNEERAT.

It was great when we had the choice to keep the old commenting format where replies were not nested. Now we have no choice, despite the fact that there were lots of intelligent criticisms of it by many of the regular and most esteemed contributors here (I might be a regular but can't claim to be esteemed). Now that choice has been taken away. As Steve L. (regular AND esteemed) points out, this nesting of replies is ONLY here on the Times site, nowhere else. So it's just the Games techies doing this and not paying any attention to UI/UX, as WE the USERS experience and use it, and ignoring our very relevant feedback. 

We know that the editors read these comments -- they sometimes comment themselves -- so why was the nearly universal rejection of this warranted?

I admit that I would like nesting employed for replies to comments  on editorials and major news stories, because a top comment there can receive dozens of responses and scrolling through all of them can be tiresome. But that doesn't happen too often here, where a robust response to a post might be a dozen or so at most, or sometimes a bit more if a certain provocateur from Warsaw is feeling his oats. But really, this is actually going to reduce commentary and response and generally effect this comments section negatively. 

Bring back the old ways!

This one nearly broke me because I originally had ‚Äúoctet‚Äù for 17D and ‚Äúerupts‚Äù for 48A. That middle section was almost completely blank for me for a while because for the life of me, I could not figure out why this original Wisconsin girl could not solve [___ and cheese] at 42D. How embarrassing!üò≥ Eventually, I just decided to try to fill in the circled letters, and I randomly guessed right! Despite the struggle, this was delightful!

Come on baby, light my FIRE.
(No time to wallow in the MIRE.)

Seriously, I saw REFI first. What's up with that?
My first Wednesday with no lookups and no checks. I'm happy. --The Noob

I'm going to be a lightning rod here.

I think I'll get used to the new comments format and learn to like it.

I think it is a truism that any change in look or feel of a page is resisted at first.  I don't know how many times a site would change its look, and I'd hate it, and a week later I couldn't even remember what the old one looked like.

So, like everyone else here, it looks confusing and weird to me.  But I think I'll adapt.  

I think the hardest thing for me to adapt to is knowing that if there is a "1 Reply" or "n Replies", I need to click that link to see them.

Anyway, I do think it's funny that we've been repeatedly asking for an Edit button, and that was *not* in the update.

For whatever reason, I never really warmed to Jerry Lee Lewis or Elvis or any of the American performers before the British Invasion.

Our family never played music, so I only started listening to it when I got to a certain age, and that age coincided with the Beatles entrance.

I'll aways wonder if I would have like American rock more at the time had it not been for the English groups.

Anyway, I never really cared for "Great Balls of Fire" except for once:  When Anthony "Goose" Edwards banged it out in "Top Gun".  That was about the only part of the movie I liked, as well.

Not a fan of any of those 1950s sounds.  Whether Elvis, Jerry Lee Lewis, or Johnny Cash.  Just a big fat, "ICK" for me.  Give me 1940s music over the 50s any day.  (Spoken as a youngish Boomer).  As for the puzzle itself, I thought it was going to be Ring of Fire.  Anybody else think that?

Dear Citizens of Carrboro, NC,
Scholars who hold masters and doctorates possess minds that we mere mortals cannot fathom. Andre does what lawyers do best... argue cases, which he appears to do quite well. If there is no case, counsellors will devise one; it's what they do. I mentioned that to him a few days back, but it got lost in last week‚Äôs Great Erasure scandal.
I've referred to a few of his highly critical comments, but gave him the credit (blame?) for it. I realize my comments can come across boorish and snarky, albeit some by design, but they pale in comparison to his poignancy and unmatched candor. Although there are other commenters here with equal zeal, his are relentless.
As Agent J says in MIB, "You know what the difference is between you and me? I make this look GOOD!" (That would be he, not I saying that)
In conclusion, unless you're either a) trying to call him out (yeah, that‚Äôll work), or b) enticing him to write a legal brief on the topic as your lesson in litigation, consider how a deep thinker's mind is wired. And, should you ever get an "Ooh, respect" reply, you've just been granted a temporary stay of execution.
Good luck with both. ;)



If this survives the cut, there are simply no standards here.

Loved this puzzle. It seemed perfect for a Wednesday. 
I haven't commented in quite awhile for various reasons, though I have been keeping up with all the puzzles. I recently starting using my laptop to do them, rather than my iPhone or my very old iPad. It has taken me some time to get used to using a different device (I'm not at all tech savvy--Baby Boomer). But I'm figuring out a bit more each day and this is the first time I was able to find the Comments. Yay!!
After reading just a few of the recent comments I see there was a change in the format (is formate the right word?). So glad I finally got here because I've missed you guys.
The country and the world keep getting more scary every day. I have dear friends in Minneapolis and in Chicago, and they are okay but I've been worried about them. I've been to one protest here in Grass Valley/Nevada City and hope to make it to more now that I'm finally over the weird flu that has been going around.
Sorry, that was verbose but it's good to be back among you.
I would never refer to REFS as "Playcallers?" This clue/answer stumped me until I got the other crossings.
I was a bit disappointed the revealer wasn't "getabetterloandeal".
Goodness gracious what a breezy Wednesday
learned a new word- Octad! I couldn't reconcile dogbreeds with octet so I knew something was amiss.
@Sam Thanks for explaining how ELS was ‚ÄúEnrollment center‚Äù. That would have bugged me not knowing what it was :)

Did anyone else get what seems to be a mistaken release of a daily Midi on their Games app dashboard on Monday? It suddenly appeared in mine on Monday with both the (undone) Sunday and Monday Midis available. I did them both and got blue stars for both of them. (The blue was slightly darker than the blue for the Mini.) They were gone from my dashboard on Tuesday and again today on Wednesday. I searched the comments for the last three days, and only found one person that commented on it, but in a reply, that person apparently did not get it on their dashboard. https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4dtel2 I suspect they are planning to implement it, and a mistake or a glitch made it appear before it was ready. I look forward to having another game to do when they roll it out.

Really enjoyed solving this puzzle and relaxed into as the song played in my head over and over! Counting letters‚Ä¶what a great way to come up with a theme. Not normally one for themed puzzles, I loved every minute of the solve. More please!
I really enjoyed this puzzle. I love the theme and how its discovery actually helps you make the solve‚Ä¶ It seems that too often themes don‚Äôt make sense..

Oh no! I just got here and as I started reading through the reader's choice comments, I realized that we no longer have a choice in how the comments display. Ugh! If I'm wrong and there's a way to turn it back the previous display, please let me know.

I wish they would have focused on fixing the things that many of us actually want, like an edit button. 

Sorry for the little whinge, but I was excited to finally have a little bit of time to check out the comments and that was a bit of a letdown. üòî 

Oh well, I hope some of you out there like the change.

This was the roughest Wednesday I‚Äôve seen in a while. Ended up scanning it into my constructor software, removing all clues and boxes, and creating my own grid from scratch.  Only way I could get through it brahs
Where is octad a word?
Uh oh, the new comments format has landed! Goodness gracious great balls of fire! I'm going up to Blueberry Hill and never coming down again.

Ahh.. one more puzzle find. A Sunday from April 4, 2004 by Manny Nosowsky with the title: "It takes all kinds." Some theme clues and answers: "Dan attacks while..." VANGUARDS "Polly punishes while..." MOLLYCODDLES "Faye rides while..." JAYWALKS "Lester bats while..." CHESTERFIELDS And some other theme answers, with similar types of clues: PENNYPINCHES NICKNAMES BOBBYSOCKS FANNYPACKS HAZELNUTS And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/4/2004&g=27&d=A ...
Trying to print the puzzle and the left margin is cut off, can't read the clues!
The Pear clue got me - I had to look it up. They're called Nashi Pears down here. But - that's two weeks in a row of Wednesday solves. Woop.
great theme! When my siblings and I were younger we did a theater camp where we performed this song, and for many years "goodness gracious, GREAT balls of fire!" was an exclamation in our family

Had a "thaw day" here today with heavy duty snow/ice clearing so only picked away at the puzzle which, was, fine. This was my first thought, and I can't belive this guy is still around (at least his website is): https://www.thegodofhellfire.com/ Did scan the comments which I see a lot of mentions that the new format went live (finally!). I've gotten used to it and my only complaint is that we need an "expand all" button to eliminate the tedium of multiple clicks on a complex thread.

Sometimes things are just too close.  I confidently put in ham to go with the cheese.  The whole middle just wasn't working.  Finally looked at the answer key.

We had MAC & cheese for dinner tonight, just before I did the puzzle.  Never occurred to me to put MAC in the puzzle!
What circled letters? My puzzle doesn't show any.
Liked the theme and the construction - but I found much of the fill to be awkward.
It is possible that the new format (which I haven't tried) will start to improve as people get used to it.

tl;dr

And with the new system, many others will not.

@Barry Ancona

I replied to your comment from last night that I was still seeing the old version. Come back this evening to find everything has changed.

The nice thing is that you get to reply directly to someone already in the reply thread and it stays under their reply rather than the original comment. It was sometimes awkward to find a reply to a reply below five other replies.

On the other hand, those five other replies were usually of interest and often worth consideration in crafting a further response, and they may not appear as prominently as they used to.

It's not like I haven't had changes in roles and had to learn new and different ways of doing things in the past. It's going to take a little time getting used to it, so I'll wait and see how it goes for a while before making any further comments about it.

commentBody: @SBK Get them to trash that confusing closing line to each post and replace it by something more legible, as follows: - replacing 'Recommendations' with ‚òÜ, making more space on the line - replacing 'x Replies' with 'x ‚úç' or a mailbox graphic, to show that it refers to already existing but hidden replies - making the 'x Replies' link open up _ALL_ replies below that level, not just the next level only I understand every second they can keep our eyeballs on the screens is money from the ad buys that are coming next. But they are walking a fine line between annoying us and driving us away. This ordure is forcing me over the line. Also, they must stop nesting replies by indenting. Instead, open each multilevel reply by using symbols to establish the level of reply. E.g., the post's opening paragraph would show ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to indicate a third-level reply. If there is no case, lawyers will make one. I mentioned that to him a few days back, but it got lost in the Great Erasure scandal.
I've referred to a few of his highly critical comments, but gave him the credit (blame?) for it. My comments can come across boorish and snarky, albeit by design, but they pale in comparison to his poignancy and unmatched candor.
As Agent J says in MIB, "You know what the difference is between you and me? I make this look GOOD!" (That would be he, not I saying that)
Unless you're either a) trying to call him out, or b) get him to write a legal brief on the topic as a lesson litigation, consider how a deep thinker's mind is wired. Good luck with both.

@Petrol If you don‚Äôt already know about the YouTube channels RobWords and Words Unravelled, I recommend you check them out. Lots of great etymology and history of the English language.
@Amaranth Thanks!
@Jane Wheelaghan what do the British call a fancy high school dance where everyone wears their shimmeriest shiniest duds?

@Jane Wheelaghan
That clue usually leads to ICES. But if you buy it premade in a can, It's usually called FROSTING. I think. I wouldn't touch the stuff.

@Lauren Ford
Well, it used to be called the leavers' disco! Low cost and pretty low-key.
Some aspects of the American 'prom' have infiltrated over the past 20 years or so and involves great expense (new clothes, hired car) with boys wearing a suit, not so much a dinner jacket (tuxedo) and girls wearing a long dress. There isn't the use of the term "a formal' to describe parties or occasions. The big flower thing has not taken off so far. 
Crowning a king and queen is not the norm either. The British would tend to poke fun at this rather than support it. My reaction is 'yuck'!
The kids don't go with a 'date' but with a group of friends, or by oneself. It's a celebration of your year group, not a romantic thing at all, and there is no pressure to ask or be asked (equally grim at any age). There can be a lot of drinking beforehand, many kids go our drinking from about age 16.

I would have been one who avoided it, mostly because of cost.

@Times Rita
I do know about frosting on a cake but it's not used that much.

commentBody:

Best of all means exactly the same as best of the best though? Let's say we are dealing with 10 poodles. 3 are by far more poodly than the other 7. Out of these 3, one is even somewhat more poodly than the other 2. This best poodle is both best of them all and the best of the best.

@Roberto

I hear you, it gave me pause too. It literally is correct, but it‚Äôs just not how we usually use BESTOFALL idiomatically. It tends to be used more adjectivally or adverbally than as a noun.

@Jerry
I am very distrustful of "genre" labels--I mean, what does "Alt-emo-rap" really mean? Several years ago, I ripped my entire CD collection into mp3s on my computer, using Windows Media Player (now Windows Media Player Legacy). In the process, I edited all the metadata for genre tags (as well as other categories), reducing them to the following categories:
Mediaeval
Renaissance
Baroque
Classical Period
19th c. Romantic
19th-20th c. Post-Romantic (basically, Mahler and Strauss)
20th c.
Contemporary (Steve Reich, Laurie Anderson, Arvo P√§rt, yadda yadda)
Jazz
Traditional/Folk
Pop (which was everything from Dolly Parton to Dead Can Dance)

Even so, there were things which fell through the cracks. Unfortunately, this edited the data only read on Windows Media Player, and not on the files themselves, so if I listen to them on any other player--my car stereo, say--it reverts to the original tags.

at Bill,
I labeled mine with a product called Tag Editor Lite. The one-time cost is minimal, but the ID3 tag suggestions are out of this world. I‚Äôm working at learning Fleetwood Mac‚Äôs ‚ÄúLandslide‚Äù for a trio gig, and here‚Äôs what ‚Äúthe network‚Äù suggested:
Blues; Pop; Rock; Classic Rock; Folk Rock; Blues Rock; Pop Rock; Soft Rock
My god (if that‚Äôs allowed here). These artists simply gave us their craft, the recording industry decides what genre to call it, and the artists‚Äô reply is probably‚Ä¶ ‚Äúis that what it‚Äôs called?‚Äù
I knew you‚Äôd pull through.

@Lewis I agree. The puzzle week should have something for everyone, including seasoned solvers looking for a challenge. I remember (many) years ago I would not even attempt a Friday or Saturday puzzle. Now, I look forward to those with relish. Tease me, test me, puzzle my brain, please.

Amen, amen, Lewis!!!!!  I knew that lots of people would get here ahead of me to say that, but it bears repeating by as many disappointed solvers as possible.  This cream-puff of a Wednesday-in-name-only puzzle is sending me back to one of my Will Shortz collections from the past (St. Martin's Press) to find a puzzle that will give my brain a real workout right now.  I strongly recommend these puzzle books for everyone who hungers for the mental stimulation they're not getting nearly often enough from the present-day NYTXW.

@Lewis Hear, hear! I understand NYT‚Äôs objective of attracting more players, especially with the expanded family memberships they are hawking. But please don‚Äôt cater exclusively to newcomers at the expense of your loyal, paying regulars!
@Lewis Since I am finding Wednesdays quite a bit easier (as a relatively new solver), it must be that the puzzles are getting easier and not that I am getting better.

@Lewis I heavy heartedly must agree! I think Saturday‚Äôs should stay hard although for Friday I don‚Äôt mind if it‚Äôs not as hard as Saturday. 

For the longest time I never wanted to say it was too easy because I know how easy for the NYT it is to tighten it up by a lot and Saturdays can still sometimes stump me at the end. But that‚Äôs as it should be.

The more I looked into VALIAN MUSIC, and "Release--Topic" as a YouTube channel, the more sure I am that this was AI-written and -"performed." Still, someone had to type into a box, "Hey, ChatGPT, write me a song about mortgage refinancing, in the style of contemporary indie-rock." But why?

@Lewis I had to go onto xwordinfo.com to remind myself of Mr. Gangi's Sondheim-themed puzzle, despite it being less than a month ago, and a puzzle I particularly enjoyed. But that reminded me of another recent Sondheim-themed puzzle, a cryptic crossword, by Our Boy Paolo, published by the New Yorker: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/cryptic-crossword/2025/12/15 I am extremely poor at British-style cryptics, and I only managed to solve this one through my knowledge of Sondheim's work--a lot of the references are quite obscure.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight -- Go back and scroll down a little.

at Bruce, It sounds like your friend may have visited Slapout, Alabama. Seriously, here's the link: https://digitalalabama.com/alabama-weird-unusual-offbeat-strange-alabama/slapout-alabama/43036/ Southerners have degrees of 'outed-ness' of a product. In reverse order, there‚Äôs: 1) Fresh out 2) Plumb out 3) Slap out The takeaway here, there‚Äôs just no coming back from being slap out. Read Lewis Grizzard. The real reason I really came here is to compliment you on authoring what will probably go down in Wordplay history as thee longest parenthetical I‚Äôve seen in my one short year of terrorizing this forum. As a next endeavor, I challenge you to try your hand at nested parentheses. Anyhow, I need to return from my break on re-wiring my HVAC unit (original HVAC techs jumbled it up badly (I have very high standards in wiring (learned from early data center days (it started out as a two-beer job (now up to three))))) Keep being Barry Anaconda!

Note to self:
Bruce, Barry and Rich (Atlanta) to me, are the same person. A triune being, I suppose. 
Apologies for any confusion.

@Jerry

I actually used to use nested parentheses a lot, often three or four deep, back when I wrote actual paper letters. I also used to put asides in footnotes, sometimes several of them, and I sometimes put in illustrations. I made a conscious effort to back off from a lot of that.

I didn't actually know where the store was when we were there. We were on our way somewhere else, stopped for food, and I happened to ask about fireworks. The owner told us that he had been talked into stocking them before the Fourth of July, had not sold even one, and now he was stuck with them at least till Christmas. He took us around, talking about what each firework did, was swearing increasingly and getting more bitter and angry by the minute. He finally just stopped, and said: "Look...I'll give you everything here for eighty bucks cash." We looked at each other, pooled our cash, hauled it all out, wedged ourselves into the Mazda MX6 amongst all the explosives, and left.

And several more stories got generated by fireworks-related incidents over the next few months. It was glorious.

@Lewis - thank you, I'm glad someone is paying attention to these things! I found the puzzle more alliterative than usual partly because of the many EEs and SSes and LL. Speaking of LLs - how many doubles did the square of 4 Ls at the bottom count as? And how about AAA?

@Lavinia -- The four L's counted as four doubles, as they appear in four answers.  When there's a triple in one word, I count it as one double, as, when going in one direction, so as not to count a letter twice in a word.
@Lewis oh right. I counted 25 doubles - 11 across, 14 down.

@Fleming The truth is, everyone was a beginner at one time‚Ä¶I doubt many (or maybe any) found even Mondays easy at one point in their solving history.

@Fleming

It shouldn‚Äôt be disheartening. We know new players are learning the ropes and everyone here is encouraging of that. But the fact of the matter that puzzles used to be more challenging as a rule and there is nothing wrong with pointing it out in the constant hope that the puzzles will return to form. That‚Äôs nothing against early week puzzles being accessible to newcomers and gradually increasing in difficulty.

@Fleming
There‚Äôs no ignominy in skipping difficult puzzles. I only did the Sunday through Wednesday puzzles until I retired and could spend the time working on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. Solve at your own pace.
@Fleming AMEN! A person can be smart but maybe not TRIVIA smart. Solving puzzles is a different kind of intelligence. R-E-S-P-E-C-T

@Fleming Don‚Äôt worry about it. I started solving when electronic editions weren‚Äôt even an idea, and I always think those puzzles in the folded up print paper were much easier. That‚Äôs because you couldn‚Äôt check your answers until the next day, and I never saved my papers (I‚Äôd drown in a sea of newsprint!), so as long as I filled in every box with something, I could tell myself I did it. üòÅ

@Fleming no worries‚Ä¶the only person you compete with is yourself. There are so many constructors who come through‚Ä¶we can‚Äôt all vibe with every constructor but I love the days that I do! Have fun solving and growing in skill. All the best
@Fleming Hey fellow beginner - not easy for me! Let's hang in there :)

commentBody: Hi John, Is this the only site using the new format? I see nested replies in editorials.

Hi Anita,

Possibly those have shifted over, too; I read Steve L.'s post this morning where he said nesting was only specific to Wordplay and didn't back check him on that. Or they might have all changed over to that, I don't really know. But thanks for letting me know. I'll do further research.
@Anita - I also see the new nested replies in all comment sections of the New York Times. Not only the Games.

@john ezra

I think you misunderstood me, or else I wasn't clear enough.  The phenomenon of long nested threads is more or less unique to this board, with so many regulars who interact with each other every day.  Not that the new system is unique to this board.

I meant to say that the new system is less problematic on other boards, where this degree of interaction among regulars is not seen.

I went to the comments on a news article I had read, and there were few third- and fourth-degree nestings.  Not because the system was different, but because there just weren't.

Hope that clarifies matters!

I like nesting OK, but it seems only the first layer of replies displays automatically, and to see deeper you have to click. You might not even notice.  My comment here is layer 3 deep - will anyone even see it?

commentBody:

And now we solve those grids in style.
So far on mobile it seems to behaving better for me.

@Francis

interesting to read about 
your musical journey
we all evolve and arrive
at various crossroads (cream)
via such varied paths

the fun irony within yours is
that the beatles idolized and 
emulated and played and dressed
like elvis and jerry and the others
during their 10,000 hour trek to mania
in england and germany 

and later sorta cleaned up their look
and really embraced the harmonies
of our black girl groups 
before ed "discovered" and 
presented them to us

so much of the british invasion
was our earlier music consumed digested
and then regurgitated through
their postwar prism and performance

and then a whole generation of
north american kids watching 
the sullivan show wanted a guitar
for their next birthday...

and then as yer brits used to say
bob's yer uncle

@rink rat tat 2 eh

üòÄ That is ironic.

When I learned how influenced the Beatles were by the earlier American acts, I was surprised.

I certainly don't disrespect pre-Beatles American acts.  It just wan't quite the sound that appealed to me.

When I was in the fourth grade, we did a "parents' show" and we all pretended to be Elvin singing "You ain't nothing but a Hound Dog".  Even then I didn't really get it.

@Francis
Rancor-free comment:
I didn‚Äôt fully embrace the whole Elvis, JLL craze either. The Stones and Beatles were a staple of you wanted to get the girls, but Mother‚Äôs Little Helper and Paperback Writer were gold! No so much Satisfaction and definitely NOT the Monkeys.

The Lovin‚Äô Spoonful
Sam The Sham & The Pharoahs
The Hollies
Steppenwolf
The Beach Boys
Orbison
Buddy Holly
Everything from the American Graffiti soundtrack 
Roger Miller
Marty Robbins

The Kryke (Red Rubber Ball)
Anything Motown
Everything Memphis Soul
Johnny Rivers
Frankie Valli
Sinatra
Mary Wells
Mamas and Papas
